title: Nautilus Q is not a knock up yet somehow it enables Yasuo to cast his ult on the target
body:
Had a winning game turn around due to this surprising functionality, I personally think this is a bug due to the fact that Nautilus Q is not a knock-up, instead it is a 'drag', by definition you cannot 'drag' something that is airborne.

Nautilus Q: Nautilus hurls his anchor forward in a line. Enemies hit are dragged towards Nautilus and he simultaneously dashes to them, dealing them magic damage and briefly stunning them.

Yasuo Ult: Yasuo blinks to the nearest visible airborne enemy champion to the cursor, instantly generating maximum Flow. Upon arriving, he suspends all nearby airborne enemies for 1 second and deals them physical damage

replies.body:
Hey, I understand the frustration, but let me see if I can help shed some light.
I believe the wording is actually key here:

To my understanding, Yasuo's R _(Last Breath)_ does not work on **Knock Ups** it works on **Airborne**. To be clear, a **Knockup** is exclusively when a target is displaced vertically. **Airborne** is when a target is displaced in any direction _(Vertically and horizontally)_ Basically if their feet leave the ground for any reason other than their own choosing, it counts as airborne, _(and being grabbed by a giant anchor would knock you off your feet, as it were :P)_

This means that Yasuo can activate his ult off pull/knockback displacement effects such as: Nautilus's Q, Blitz's Q, and Darius's E, as well as regular knockup effects such as Fizz's R, Vi's R, Malphite's R, Yasuo's Q, etc etc. So because the champion's feet leave the ground, they are technically airborne, even if only briefly.

The only displacement effect that Yasuo can not ult off _(to my knowledge)_, is Poppy's R, as Keepers verdict causes it's targets to be untargetable for the duration. 

If Yasuo's R worked only on knockups, then it wouldnt work on Nami's Q, as Aqua Prison does not **knock up** enemies, it **suspends** them.

So I think that it is intended that Yasuo can ult off Nautilus's Q.

Yes I would agree with the difference between knock up and airborne and I agree with your' statement:
"Basically if their feet leave the ground for any reason other than their own choosing, it counts as airborne"

I think my only remaining complaint if we are to assume that being grabbed by a giant anchor knocks you off your' feet is that the wording of Nautilus Q should be updated because I stand with my original point:
"...you cannot 'drag' something that is airborne"

Thanks for the insight =]

I must agree that the wording is often misleading _(and not just with Nautilus either)_

Both Nautilus's Q and Skarner's R are referred to as a 'drag', yet both have completely different CC effects.

Naut's Q is a knockback/pull displacement (pops Taliyah's Rocks, and activates Yasuo's R), while Skarner's R is a suppression (which neither breaks the rocks nor 
activates Yasuo's Ult).

But they are both called the same thing?

I personally reckon there needs to be a cleanup of wording across the whole of league. 
_(and also take another look at what classes as a 'projectile' as Taliyah's R and Azir's Q should not be blocked by Braum/Yasuo's walls)_
Yasuo should be able to ult zac mid air tbh, would be a nice counterplay mechanic to a zac launching in with ori ball on him.

> by definition you cannot 'drag' something that is airborne.

I'm going to have to call bullsh!t on this. While there are many, *many* definitions for the word "drag" (and my god, I never realised a single word could have so many definitions), not a single one of them indicates in any way that "you cannot drag something that is airborne".

Don't believe me? Take a good, long look for yourself (and prepare for *lots* of reading): https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/drag
Thresh Q?!? Wow, now that makes Nautilus Q seem reasonable by comparison XD
